title: Psalms Chapter 81 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 81 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 81 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 81.

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:1, to whom is the Psalm directed?
questions.correctAnswer: The chief Musician upon Gittith
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:1 begins with 'To the chief Musician upon Gittith, A Psalm of Asaph.' indicating the direction.

questions.question: What instruments are mentioned in Psalms 81:2 for making music?
questions.correctAnswer: Timbrel and psaltery
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:2 says, 'Take a psalm, and bring hither the timbrel, the pleasant harp with the psaltery.'

questions.question: When does Psalms 81:3 instruct to blow the trumpet?
questions.correctAnswer: During the new moon
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:3 states, 'Blow up the trumpet in the new moon.'

questions.question: What was the statute mentioned in Psalms 81:4 for?
questions.correctAnswer: For Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:4 says, 'For this was a statute for Israel.'

questions.question: In Psalms 81:5, where did God hear a language He did not understand?
questions.correctAnswer: Land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:5 states, 'when he went out through the land of Egypt: where I heard a language that I understood not.'

questions.question: What did God do to Israel according to Psalms 81:6?
options: Removed his shoulder from the burden
questions.correctAnswer: Removed his shoulder from the burden
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:6 says, 'I removed his shoulder from the burden: his hands were delivered from the pots.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:7, where did God answer Israel?
options: In the secret place of thunder
questions.correctAnswer: In the secret place of thunder
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:7 states, 'I answered thee in the secret place of thunder.'

questions.question: What condition is given in Psalms 81:8 for God to testify unto His people?
options: If thou wilt hearken unto me
questions.correctAnswer: If thou wilt hearken unto me
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:8 says, 'O Israel, if thou wilt hearken unto me.'

questions.question: What is forbidden in Psalms 81:9?
questions.correctAnswer: Worshipping any strange god
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:9 states, 'There shall no strange god be in thee; neither shalt thou worship any strange god.'

questions.question: Who does Psalms 81:10 say brought Israel out of Egypt?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD thy God
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:10 says, 'I am the LORD thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 81:11 states that Israel listened carefully to God's voice.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:11 says, 'But my people would not hearken to my voice; and Israel would none of me.'

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 81:12, Israel walked in their own counsels.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:12 says, 'they walked in their own counsels.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 81:13 expresses a wish for Israel to have obeyed God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:13 states, 'Oh that my people had hearkened unto me, and Israel had walked in my ways!'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 81:16: 'He should have fed them also with the finest of the ______:'
questions.correctAnswer: wheat
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:16 says, 'He should have fed them also with the finest of the wheat.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:14, what would God have done if Israel had walked in His ways?
questions.correctAnswer: Subdued their enemies
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:14 states, 'I should soon have subdued their enemies.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 81 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 81 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81 teach us about praising God in our daily lives?
options: By singing aloud and making a joyful noise unto God
By remaining silent and meditating quietly
questions.correctAnswer: By singing aloud and making a joyful noise unto God
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:1 encourages us to sing aloud and make a joyful noise unto God, showing that open, joyful praise is a vital part of our devotion. This is supported by verses 2-3 where musical instruments are called for in worship.

questions.question: What biblical principle about worship and celebration is taught in Psalms 81:3?
options: Blow the trumpet on the new moon and appointed feast days
questions.correctAnswer: Blow the trumpet on the new moon and appointed feast days
questions.explanation: Verse 3 instructs to blow the trumpet in the new moon and on solemn feast days, teaching that God’s people should celebrate His goodness regularly and publicly with joyful noise and music.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81 describe God's deliverance of Israel from hardship, and what does this teach about trusting God?
options: God removed their burden and delivered their hands from the pots
God left them to suffer without help
Israel saved themselves by their own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God removed their burden and delivered their hands from the pots
questions.explanation: Verse 6 shows that God relieved Israel’s burdens, symbolizing His care and power to deliver us from trials when we trust Him. This teaches us to rely on God’s strength rather than our own efforts.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with temptation and seeks encouragement. What does Psalms 81:7 teach about God's response to our calls for help?
options: God hears us in trouble and delivers us
questions.correctAnswer: God hears us in trouble and delivers us
questions.explanation: Verse 7 says that when Israel called in trouble, God delivered them and answered from the secret place of thunder, encouraging us to call on God confidently in our trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81:8-9 emphasize the importance of faithfulness in our relationship with God?
options: No strange god should be in thee; worship only the LORD
Worship many gods to ensure blessings
Choose gods that suit personal desires
questions.correctAnswer: No strange god should be in thee; worship only the LORD
questions.explanation: Verses 8-9 warn against idolatry and call for exclusive worship of the LORD, highlighting faithfulness and obedience as key to a strong relationship with God.

questions.question: What promise does God give to those who obey Him, according to Psalms 81:10?
options: Open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it
God will be distant and silent
You must earn blessings by works alone
questions.correctAnswer: Open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it
questions.explanation: Verse 10 promises that if we trust and obey God, He will provide abundantly for our needs, teaching us to rely on His provision rather than worry.

questions.question: What does Psalms 81:11-12 teach us about the consequences of ignoring God's voice?
options: We are given up to follow our own desires and counsels
questions.correctAnswer: We are given up to follow our own desires and counsels
questions.explanation: These verses explain that when people reject God’s guidance, He allows them to follow their own lusts and plans, which often leads to hardship, teaching the importance of obedience.

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:13-14, what would have been the result if Israel had obeyed God's ways?
options: God would have subdued their enemies and turned His hand against adversaries
Israel would have remained weak and defeated
questions.correctAnswer: God would have subdued their enemies and turned His hand against adversaries
questions.explanation: These verses show God’s desire to protect and bless His people if they obey, encouraging believers that faithful living leads to divine protection and victory.

questions.question: What does Psalms 81:15 teach about the fate of those who hate the LORD?
options: They would submit to Him, but their time would endure forever
They would be immediately forgiven without repentance
questions.correctAnswer: They would submit to Him, but their time would endure forever
questions.explanation: Verse 15 indicates that enemies of God would eventually be humbled but face lasting punishment, teaching the seriousness of opposing God and encouraging repentance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81:16 illustrate God's provision and care for His people?
options: He would feed them with the finest wheat and honey out of the rock
He would leave them hungry and thirsty
He would provide only basic needs sparingly
He would punish them with famine
questions.correctAnswer: He would feed them with the finest wheat and honey out of the rock
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes God's abundant and satisfying provision, reminding believers of His care and encouraging trust in His generosity.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 81 calls God's people to exclusive worship of Him, rejecting any strange gods.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 9 explicitly states that no strange god should be in Israel and they should not worship any other deity, emphasizing exclusive devotion to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 81, God is indifferent to whether His people obey His voice or not.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 11-13 show that God deeply desires obedience and is grieved when His people refuse to listen, demonstrating His active concern for their faithfulness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "I am the LORD thy God, which brought thee out of the land of Egypt: open thy mouth wide, and I will ______ it."
questions.correctAnswer: fill
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:10 promises that God will fill the mouths of His people if they trust Him, symbolizing provision and blessing for those who obey.

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:5, what event serves as a testimony ordained by God for Israel?
options: When Joseph went out through the land of Egypt
When Moses received the Ten Commandments
questions.correctAnswer: When Joseph went out through the land of Egypt
questions.explanation: Verse 5 references God’s ordaining of a testimony in Joseph during his journey through Egypt, reminding Israel of God's faithfulness in their history.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81:2 encourage a spirit of worship in believers?
options: By taking a psalm and using musical instruments like timbrel and harp
By praying silently without any instruments
By isolating oneself from church fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: By taking a psalm and using musical instruments like timbrel and harp
questions.explanation: Verse 2 encourages the use of joyful music in worship, demonstrating that active, expressive praise strengthens faith and fellowship.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 81 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 81.

questions.question: What musical instruments are specifically mentioned in Psalms 81:2 for making a joyful noise unto God?
questions.correctAnswer: Timbrel, harp, psaltery
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:2 explicitly mentions the timbrel, the pleasant harp, and the psaltery as instruments to accompany the psalm.

questions.question: In Psalms 81:3, what event is the trumpet blown for?
options: New moon and solemn feast day
questions.correctAnswer: New moon and solemn feast day
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:3 states the trumpet is blown on the new moon and at the appointed solemn feast day, marking sacred times for Israel.

questions.question: According to Psalms 81:5, what historical event is referenced as a testimony for Israel?
options: The giving of the law at Sinai
questions.correctAnswer: Joseph going out through Egypt
questions.explanation: Verse 5 specifically mentions 'when he went out through the land of Egypt' referring to Joseph's experiences as a testimony for Israel.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'I removed his shoulder from the burden' in Psalms 81:6?
options: The Ark of the Covenant was carried
questions.correctAnswer: God delivered Israel from slavery
questions.explanation: This phrase metaphorically refers to God freeing Israel from the heavy burdens of Egyptian slavery, as described in Psalms 81:6.

questions.question: In Psalms 81:7, what locations or events symbolize God’s testing and deliverance of Israel?
options: Secret place of thunder and waters of Meribah
Mount Sinai and Red Sea crossing
questions.correctAnswer: Secret place of thunder and waters of Meribah
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:7 references God's revelation in the thunder and testing at Meribah, symbolizing both judgment and deliverance.

questions.question: How does Psalms 81:8 express the relationship between God and Israel?
options: God testifies and calls Israel to listen
questions.correctAnswer: God testifies and calls Israel to listen
questions.explanation: Verse 8 shows God speaking directly, urging Israel to hear and respond to His testimony, emphasizing covenantal communication.

questions.question: What is forbidden in Psalms 81:9 as a condition for Israel's faithfulness?
options: No strange god shall be in thee
questions.correctAnswer: No strange god shall be in thee
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:9 commands that Israel must not have or worship any strange god, enforcing exclusive worship of Yahweh.

questions.question: Psalms 81:10 contains a promise from the LORD. What is that promise?
options: Open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it
I will give you many descendants
I will grant you peace forever
I will make you kings over nations
questions.correctAnswer: Open thy mouth wide, and I will fill it
questions.explanation: In verse 10, God promises provision and blessing if Israel obeys, using the metaphor of filling an open mouth.

questions.question: What was Israel’s response to God’s voice according to Psalms 81:11?
options: They would not hearken to God
They built altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They would not hearken to God
questions.explanation: Verse 11 explains that Israel rejected God’s voice and chose not to listen to Him, indicating disobedience.

questions.question: What consequence does God describe in Psalms 81:12 for Israel's disobedience?
options: Given up to their own heart’s lust
questions.correctAnswer: Given up to their own heart’s lust
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that God gave Israel over to their own desires and plans as a result of their refusal to listen.

questions.question: Which literary device is most evident in the contrast between verses 11 and 13 of Psalms 81?
questions.correctAnswer: Antithesis
questions.explanation: Verses 11 and 13 juxtapose Israel’s refusal to listen with a longing for obedience, showcasing antithesis between disobedience and ideal faithfulness.

questions.question: What does God claim He would have done if Israel had hearkened, according to Psalms 81:14?
options: Subdued their enemies and turned His hand against adversaries
Built a temple in their midst
Made them rulers over the nations
questions.correctAnswer: Subdued their enemies and turned His hand against adversaries
questions.explanation: Verse 14 expresses God’s promise to defeat Israel’s enemies if they obeyed Him.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 81:15, the haters of the LORD would have submitted themselves to Him if Israel obeyed.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 clearly states that the haters of the LORD would have submitted themselves had Israel obeyed, indicating the power of Israel’s obedience.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 81:16 to describe God's provision for Israel?
options: Fed with the finest wheat and honey from the rock
Given a crown of gold and silver
questions.correctAnswer: Fed with the finest wheat and honey from the rock
questions.explanation: Verse 16 uses the metaphor of fine wheat and honey from the rock to depict abundant and miraculous provision.

questions.question: Psalms 81 is attributed to which author and is directed to which audience?
questions.correctAnswer: Asaph; the people of Israel
questions.explanation: The superscription in Psalms 81:1 identifies Asaph as the psalmist, and the psalm addresses Israel as God's people.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 81 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 81 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Psalms 81 for singing aloud and making a joyful noise to God?
options: Because He is full of wrath
questions.correctAnswer: Because He is our strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:1 calls God 'our strength,' emphasizing the reason for joyful praise. This aligns with scriptures like Exodus 15:2, Nehemiah 8:10, Psalm 28:7, Isaiah 12:2, and Hebrews 12:28 that affirm God as our strength and reason for rejoicing.

questions.question: Which musical instruments are specifically mentioned in Psalms 81 to accompany the psalm?
questions.correctAnswer: Timbrel, harp, and psaltery
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:2 instructs to bring the timbrel and the pleasant harp with the psaltery. This reflects the biblical tradition of using these instruments in worship as seen in 2 Samuel 6:5, 1 Chronicles 13:8, Psalm 33:2, Psalm 150:4, and Amos 6:5.

questions.question: According to Psalms 81, when is the trumpet supposed to be blown?
options: In the new moon and on our solemn feast day
Only at the end of the year
questions.correctAnswer: In the new moon and on our solemn feast day
questions.explanation: Psalms 81:3 specifies blowing the trumpet in the new moon and appointed solemn feast days, consistent with Leviticus 23:24, Numbers 10:10, Joshua 6:4, Nehemiah 12:35, and Hebrews 12:22-23 where trumpets signal God's appointed times.

questions.question: What does Psalms 81 identify as a statute and law for Israel?
options: Blowing the trumpet on the new moon and feast days
questions.correctAnswer: Blowing the trumpet on the new moon and feast days
questions.explanation: Verse 4 states this practice was a statute and law from God, confirming the importance of these appointed times (cf. Exodus 12:14, Leviticus 23, Numbers 28:11, Deuteronomy 16:16, Psalm 81:3).

questions.question: What event in Israel’s history does Psalms 81 use as a testimony of God's deliverance?
questions.correctAnswer: The exodus from Egypt
questions.explanation: Verse 5 references God’s deliverance through Egypt, showing His saving power. This theme is echoed in Exodus 12:51, Deuteronomy 6:21, Psalm 78:12, Isaiah 63:11, and John 1:29, which highlight God’s redemptive acts.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 81 to describe God removing Israel’s burdens?
options: Removing the shoulder from the burden and delivering hands from the pots
Breaking chains and opening prison doors
Parting the sea and leading through the wilderness
Building a strong tower for refuge
questions.correctAnswer: Removing the shoulder from the burden and delivering hands from the pots
questions.explanation: Verse 6 uses this metaphor to portray liberation from slavery. Similar imagery of deliverance appears in Exodus 3:7-8, Isaiah 42:7, Galatians 5:1, Psalm 107:13, and Luke 4:18.

questions.question: How does God describe His response to Israel's call in times of trouble in Psalms 81?
options: He delivered them and answered in the secret place of thunder
He ignored their cries and remained distant
He sent prophets to rebuke them only
questions.correctAnswer: He delivered them and answered in the secret place of thunder
questions.explanation: Verse 7 describes God's powerful and hidden response, affirming His faithfulness. This resonates with Exodus 19:16-19, Psalm 29:3-9, Deuteronomy 5:23, Hebrews 12:19, and Revelation 4:5.

questions.question: What condition does God set for Israel to receive His testimony according to Psalms 81?
options: If they fast twice a week
questions.correctAnswer: If they hearken to Him
questions.explanation: Verse 8 calls for Israel to listen and obey. This covenantal condition is consistent with Deuteronomy 6:4-5, Jeremiah 7:23, John 14:15, Proverbs 1:33, and Romans 10:17 emphasizing obedience to God’s word.

questions.question: What does God forbid Israel from having in their hearts according to Psalms 81?
questions.correctAnswer: Strange gods
questions.explanation: Verse 9 clearly prohibits worshiping any strange god. This is foundational to monotheism and is reiterated in Exodus 20:3, Deuteronomy 5:7, Isaiah 45:5, 1 Corinthians 8:4, and 1 John 5:21.

questions.question: What promise does God make to Israel if they open their mouths wide according to Psalms 81?
questions.correctAnswer: He will fill them
questions.explanation: Verse 10 promises provision if Israel trusts God. This reflects God's providence as in Psalm 23:1, John 6:35, Philippians 4:19, Isaiah 58:11, and Matthew 5:6.

questions.question: What was Israel's response to God's voice as described in Psalms 81?
options: They would not hearken and none of God
questions.correctAnswer: They would not hearken and none of God
questions.explanation: Verse 11 reveals Israel’s rebellion and refusal to listen, highlighting human sinfulness (cf. Exodus 32:9, Judges 2:11, Romans 3:23, Hebrews 3:15, and John 12:37).

questions.question: What consequence does God declare for Israel’s refusal to listen in Psalms 81?
options: He gave them up to their own hearts’ lusts
He sent immediate judgment without warning
questions.correctAnswer: He gave them up to their own hearts’ lusts
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states God allowed them to follow their own desires, illustrating divine judgment through permission. This principle is seen in Romans 1:24, Judges 21:25, Proverbs 1:29, Isaiah 65:2, and 2 Thessalonians 2:11.

questions.question: What blessing does God say He would have given if Israel had hearkened to Him in Psalms 81?
options: He would have subdued their enemies
He would have taken away their wealth
He would have hidden His face
questions.correctAnswer: He would have subdued their enemies
questions.explanation: Verse 14 promises victory over enemies if Israel obeyed, affirming God's protective and victorious nature (cf. Exodus 23:22, 2 Samuel 22:39, Isaiah 54:17, Romans 8:31, and Revelation 19:11).

questions.question: According to Psalms 81, what would have happened to the haters of the LORD if Israel had obeyed?
options: They would have submitted to Him
They would have triumphed over Israel
They would have fled into exile
questions.correctAnswer: They would have submitted to Him
questions.explanation: Verse 15 states that enemies hating the LORD would have submitted, demonstrating God’s sovereign rule. This is consistent with Isaiah 45:23, Philippians 2:10, Psalm 18:44, Romans 14:11, and Revelation 15:4.

questions.question: What provision does God say He would have given Israel if they obeyed, as described in Psalms 81?
options: The finest wheat and honey out of the rock
The land of Canaan without struggle
questions.correctAnswer: The finest wheat and honey out of the rock
questions.explanation: Verse 16 promises abundant provision symbolized by finest wheat and honey from the rock, echoing Exodus 3:8, Deuteronomy 8:7-10, Psalm 19:10, Matthew 3:4, and John 6:35 where God satisfies spiritually and physically.
